Science. 2001; 292: 468-472Crossref PubMed Scopus (4489) Google Scholar). To that end, Gal4-HIF1α-(498–574) was constructed and analyzed for in vitro VHL binding. Remarkably, addition of a single leucine residue to Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573) gained VHL binding (Fig.5 a, lanes 1 and2), whereas mutation of Leu-574 to serine abolished the binding (lane 3), indicating an essential role for Leu-574 in VHL binding. To corroborate the importance of Leu-574, we also mutated Leu-574 in Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603) and asked whether substitution with serine would affect VHL binding. Consistently, the mutation resulted in the loss of VHL binding (compare lane 4and lane 5). Thus, these results provide compelling evidence that Leu-574 is critically involved in VHL binding. To address the role of Leu-574 in protein stability, we examined expression levels of these constructs by Western blot analysis. In comparison with Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573), Gal4-HIF1α-(498–574) exhibited an ∼3-fold decrease in protein levels under normoxia (Fig.5 b, compare lane 1 and lane 3), supporting the role of Leu-574 in VHL-mediated degradation. Consistently, mutation of Leu-574 prevented the degradation process, resulting in a stable Gal4-HIF1α-(498–574) (compare lane 3 and lane 5). Furthermore, mutation of Leu-574 gave rise to a 7-fold increase in the expression level of Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603) (compare lane 7 and lane 9). Taken together, these results demonstrate that Leu-574 plays a critical role in the VHL degradation pathway, although additional residues between amino acids 575–603 may also contribute oxygen-dependent degradation of the C-terminal ODD. As shown above, the core NAD lies within amino acids 498–573 of HIF-1α. To examine the effect of Leu-574 on transcriptional activity, we employed the aforementioned Gal4 luciferase reporter system. As expected, the addition of Leu-574 significantly lowered the luciferase reporter activity (Fig. 5 c) by 6.5-fold under normoxia. In contrast, Gal4-HIF1α-(498–574)L574S gave rise to a similar reporter activity as that of Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573), supporting the involvement of Leu-574 in ODD instability. Furthermore, under oxygenated conditions, Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603)L574S exhibited a 4.3-fold increase in luciferase activity in comparison with the wild-type. Therefore, these results provide further evidence that Leu-574 plays a critical role in VHL-mediated degradation of HIF-1α, thereby regulating HIF-1α transcriptional activity. In this study, we demonstrate that Leu-574 is indispensable to VHL binding in vitro and in vivo and to VHL-mediated degradation. This finding is based on the evidence that (i) unlike Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603), Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573) was unable to bind to VHL, and therefore, constitutively expressed; (ii) the addition of Leu-574 to Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573) resulted in a gain of VHL binding and a loss of protein stability; (iii) the mutation of Leu-574 in Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603) led to a decrease in VHL binding and an increase in protein stability; and (iv) Leu-574 is highly conserved in HIF-1α, HIF-2α, and HIF-3α. It is noteworthy, however, that the biological function of Leu-574 may go beyond VHL binding per se. It is equally possible that this residue participates in the interaction of the C-terminal ODD with HIF-1α prolyl hydroxylases. Consequently, lack or mutation of Leu-574 would prevent Pro-564 hydroxylation, thereby resulting in protein stabilization and loss of VHL binding. In fact, this hypothesis is consistent with recent structural studies of VHL-HIF1α interaction, which concluded that hydroxyproline Pro-564 provides strict specificity for VHL recognition, whereas the neighboring amino acid residues only contribute to the complex stability through a β sheet-like contact (33Hon W.C. Chem. 1997; 272: 19253-19260Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (556) Google Scholar) of protein stability was proposed. All of these studies, however, showed that NAD transcriptional activity was hypoxia-dependent. In this report, we demonstrated that the core NAD lies between amino acids 498–573 and confers constitutive transcriptional activity irrespective of changes in oxygen tension. Our finding suggests that the NAD possesses an intrinsic (or hypoxia-independent) transcriptional activity. In keeping with this notion, addition of Leu-574 to Gal4-HIF1α-(498–573) regained VHL binding, normoxic degradation, and therefore normoxic repression (or hypoxic induction) of transcription. Conversely, Leu-574 mutation in Gal4-HIF1α-(498–603) produced the opposite effects. Thus, NAD transcriptional activity is constitutive and dependent upon protein stability. In summary, degradation of HIF-1α is a complex process, at least involving VHL binding to the N-terminal and C-terminal ODD independently. Leu-574 of HIF-1α is crucial for in vivoVHL binding and VHL-mediated degradation, possibly through direct contact with VHL or with HIF prolyl hydroxylases. Regardless of the precise mechanism, our finding may provide a molecular basis for the development of therapeutic agents to alter HIF-1α function. We are indebted to H. F. Bunn. for generous support and encouragement of this work. We thank W. G. Kaelin, Jr. for reagents, Xin W. Wang for critical reading of the manuscript, and Dorothea Dudek for editorial assistance.

We previously reported that proinflammatory mediator bradykinin (BK) induces cyclooxygenase (COX)-2 expression in human airway smooth muscle (HASM), but the mechanism is unknown in any biological system. Here, we studied the role of specific protein kinase C (PKC) isozyme(s) in COX-2 expression. Among the eight PKC isozymes present in HASM cells, the Ca2+-independent PKC-delta and -epsilon and the Ca2+-dependent PKC-alpha and -betaI were translocated to the nucleus upon BK stimulation. BK-induced COX-2 expression and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) accumulation were mimicked by the direct PKC activator phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) and inhibited by the broad spectrum PKC inhibitor bisindolylmaleimide I. However, the selective Ca2+-dependent PKC isozyme inhibitor Go 6976 had no effect. Furthermore, the membrane-permeable calcium chelator BAPTA-AM had no effect on BK-induced COX-2 expression and COX activity despite its inhibition of PGE2 accumulation, suggesting the involvement of Ca2+-independent PKC isozymes. Rottlerin, a PKC-delta inhibitor, also had no effect, likely implicating PKC-epsilon. BK-stimulated transcriptional activation of a COX-2 promoter reporter construct was enhanced by overexpression of wild-type PKC-epsilon and abolished by a dominant negative PKC-epsilon, but it was not affected by wild-type or dominant negative PKC-alpha or -delta. Collectively, our results demonstrate that PKC-e mediates BK-induced COX-2 expression in HASM cells.

Apoptosis is the major independent form of cardiomyocyte cell death in acute myocardial infarction (AMI). TNF-alpha release early in the course of AMI contributes to myocardial injury, and TNF-alpha induces apoptosis in cardiomyocytes. Soluble TNF-alpha receptor 1 (sTNFR1) is an antagonist to TNF-alpha. However, the effect of sTNFR1 on AMI remains unclear. Here we report that direct injection of an sTNFR1 expression plasmid DNA to the myocardium reduces infarct size in experimental rat AMI. Treatment with sTNFR1 expression plasmid DNA reduced the TNF-alpha bioactivity in the myocardium and the apoptosis of cardiomyocytes. These findings suggest that the anti-TNF-alpha therapy by sTNFR1 can be a new strategy for treatment of AMI.

The three-dimensional solution structure of an acidic fibroblast growth factor (nFGF-1) from the newt (Notophthalmus viridescens) is determined using multidimensional NMR techniques. Complete assignment of all the atoms (1H, 15N, and 13C) has been achieved using a variety of triple resonance experiments. 50 structures were calculated using hybrid distance geometry-dynamical simulated annealing technique with a total of 1359 constraints. The atomic root mean square distribution for the backbone atoms in the structured region is 0.60 Å. The secondary structural elements include 12 β-strands arranged antiparallely into a β-barrel structure. The protein (nFGF-1) exists in a monomeric state upon binding to the ligand, sucrose octa sulfate (SOS), in a stoichiometric ratio of 1:1. The SOS binding site consists of a dense cluster of positively charged residues located at the C-terminal end of the molecule. The conformational stabilities of nFGF-1 and its structural and functional homologue from the human source (hFGF-1) are drastically different. The differential stabilities of nFGF-1 and hFGF-1 are attributed to the differences in the number of hydrogen bonds and the presence of solvent inaccessible cavities in the two proteins. Amino acid sequence comparison indicates that nFGF-1 exhibits about 80% homology with its mammalian counterparts (Fig.1). nFGF-1 has been shown to elicit a mitogenic response, which is similar to that exhibited by the human FGF-1 (hFGF-1, Ref. 28Patrie K.M. Ray S.K. Mehta V.B. Chiu I.M. Growth Factors. 1997; 14: 39-57Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). In this context, we determine the three-dimensional structure(s) of nFGF-1 using a variety of multidimensional NMR techniques. In addition, we also compare the thermodynamic stabilities of hFGF-1 and nFGF-1 and attempt to rationalize the observed difference(s) in the conformational stabilities based on their three-dimensional structures. Plasmid DNA was prepared using a mini-prep kit obtained from Qiagen (Germany). EcoRI and XbaI were purchased from New England Biolabs. Ampicillin and chloramphenicol were procured from AMERSCO. Ingredients for the LB medium were obtained from DIFCO laboratories. Low molecular weight heparin (M r∼3000), phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, aprotinin, pepstatin, leupeptin, Triton X-100, β-mercaptoethanol, and α-chymotrypsin were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. Sucrose octosulfate (SOS) was purchased from Toronto Research Chemicals (Canada). Heparin-Sepharose was procured from Amersham Biosciences. All other chemicals used were of high quality analytical grade. All solutions were made in Milli Q water. Unless otherwise mentioned, all experiments were performed in 10 mm phosphate buffer (pH 7. 2) containing 100 mmNaCl. Recombinant hFGF-1 and nFGF-1) were prepared from transformed Escherichia coli BL21(DE3)pLysS. The nFGF-1 DNA construct consisting of 486 base pairs was inserted between the NdeI and BamH1 restriction sites. The expressed proteins were purified on a heparin-Sepharose affinity column over a NaCl gradient (0–1.5 m). Desalting of the purified protein was achieved by ultrafiltration using an Amicon set-up. The purity of the protein was assessed using SDS-PAGE. The authenticity of the truncated sample was verified by ES-Mass analysis. The concentration of the protein was estimated based on its extinction coefficient value at 280 nm. Uniform15N and 13C isotope labeling (of human and newt FGF-1) were achieved using M9 minimal medium containing15NH4Cl and (13C6)-glucose (30Gardner K.H. Kay L.E. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struc. 1998; 27: 357-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (514) Google Scholar). In order to realize maximal expression yields, the composition of the M9 medium was modified by the addition of a mixture mixture of vitamins. The expression host strain E. coli BL21(DE3)pLysS is a vitamin B1-deficient host and hence the medium was supplemented with thiamine (vitamin B1). Protein expression yields were in the range of 25–30 mg/liter of the isotope-enriched medium. The extent of 15N labeling was verified by ES-Mass analysis. The thermodynamic stability of the protein was assessed from the urea denaturation experiments. Fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-2500 fluorimeter at 2.5 or 10 nm resolution, using an excitation wavelength of 295 nm. Unless otherwise mentioned, all fluorescence measurements were made using a protein concentration of 100 μg/ml in 10 mmphosphate buffer containing 100 mm NaCl and 100 mm ammonium sulfate. The fraction of unfolded species was estimated from the ratio of the emission intensities at 308 nm and 350 nm. Equilibrium unfolding data obtained were converted to plots of FU, the fraction of the protein in the unfolded state, versus denaturant concentration using Equation 1, FU=(XD−(XF+mF[D])/{(XU+mU[D])−(XF+mF[D])}Equation 1 where, XD is the value of the spectroscopic property measured at denaturant concentration [D]. XF and XU represent the intercepts, and mF and mU are the slopes of the folded and unfolded baselines of the data, respectively, and were obtained from the linear least square fits of the baselines. For a two state (Native ⇆ Denatured) unfolding pathway, the free energy of unfolding by denaturant (ΔG U) at concentration [D] is related toF U by transformation of the Gibbs-Helmholtz equation. It is assumed that the free energy of unfolding ΔG U, has a linear dependence on the concentration of the denaturant [D] according to Equation 2, ΔGU=ΔG(H2O)+m[D]Equation 2 where, ΔG (H2O) andm are the intercept and slope, respectively of the plot of ΔG U versus the concentration of the denaturant. m is the measure of the co-operativity of the unfolding reaction, and ΔG (H2O) is the change in free energy for a transition from folded to unfolded state(s) in the absence of the denaturant. Sedimentation velocity experiments were performed on a Beckman-Coulter Optima XL-A analytical ultracentrifuge equipped with An-60 Ti analytical rotor and standard double sector cells. Sedimentation velocity experiments on nFGF-1 (in the presence and absence of SOS) were performed under identical conditions. Sedimentation velocity Experiments were performed at 4 °C at 50,000 rpm for 20 h. The Svedberg constant (S20,w) values were estimated using standard methods. The sedimentation boundary movement was traced by the absorbance of the protein using an inbuilt UV detector. The protein to ligand (SOS) ratio used in these experiments was 1:1. The concentration of the protein (nFGF-1) used was 1.5 mg/ml NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker DMX 600 MHz spectrometer. For the two- and three-dimensional heteronuclear experiments, the concentration of the protein used was about 1 mm. The protein samples were prepared in 10 mm phosphate buffer containing 100 mm ammonium sulfate, 0.1 mm mercaptoethanol, 0.1 mm EDTA in the presence and absence of SOS. All NMR data were acquired at 25 ± 0.5 °C. Homonuclear two-dimensional experiments [TOCSY (mixing time 75 ms), DQF-COSY, NOESY (mixing time 200 ms)] were acquired on unlabeled nFGF-1. All heteronuclear two- and three-dimensional experiments were performed on a uniformly 13C/15N-labeled protein (31Bax A. Grzesiek S. Acc. Chem. Res. 1993; 26: 130-138Crossref Scopus (796) Google Scholar, 32Clore G.M. Gronenborn A.M. Protein Sci. 1991; 3: 379-391Google Scholar). The three-dimensional NMR experiments performed on nFGF-1 include, HNHA, HNCA, HNCO, HN(CA)CO, CBCA(CO)NH, CC(CO)NH, HCCH-TOCSY, 13C HSQC-TOCSY, 15N HSQC-TOCSY, 13C HSQC-NOESY, and 15N HSQC-NOESY. DSS was used as an internal standard for calibration of the proton resonances. For 15N and 13C chemical shift calibration, we followed the IUPAC procedure defined by Markleyet al. (33Markley J.L. Bax A. Arata Y. Hilbers C.W. Kaptein R. Sykes B.D. Wright P.E. Wuthrich K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 256: 1-15Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). The water resonance was suppressed by applying a WATERGATE sequence or by presaturation. The three-dimensional spectra were processed and analyzed using the standard Bruker software XWINNMR and AURELIA. A 200-ms 13C F1-filtered, F3-edited NOESY experiment was recorded on 13C/15N-labeled nFGF-1 and unlabeled SOS complex at 600 MHz using the pulse sequence described by Lee et al. (34Lee W. Revington M.J. Arrowsmith C. Kay L.E. FEBS Lett. 1994; 350: 87-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). A data matrix consisting of 36 × 16 × 1024 complex points in each of t1, t2, and t3 was acquired. Spectral width of 6614 × 3924 × 2400 Hz was employed in the F1, F2, and F3 dimensions, with corresponding acquisition times of 154, 4, and 15 ms, respectively. 128 scans were acquired for each FID, and the total acquisition time was about 106 h. The structures were calculated using the hybrid distance geometry-dynamical simulated annealing method of Nilges et al. (35Nilges M. Gronenborn A.M. Brunger A.T. Clore G.M. Protein Eng. 1988; 2: 27-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (516) Google Scholar) using the program X-PLOR (36Brunger A.T. X-PLOR Software Manual, Version 3.1. Yale University, New Haven, CT1992Google Scholar) adopted to incorporate pseudo potentials for the 3JNHαcoupling constants (37Kuszewski J. Qin J. Gronenborn A.M. Clore G.M. J. Mag. Reson. 1995; 106: 92-96Crossref Scopus (190) Google Scholar) and secondary13Cα/13Cβ chemical shift restraints (38Kuszewski J. Gronenborn A.M. Clore G.M. J. Mag. Reson. 1995; 107: 293-297Crossref Scopus (110) Google Scholar). The target function that is minimized during restraint minimization and simulated annealing only comprises of quadratic harmonic terms for covalent geometry, 3J coupling constants and13Cα/13Cβ chemical shift restraints. NOE data were extracted from two- and three-dimensional NOESY experiments. To avoid over estimation of NOE intensities due to a contribution of zero quantum coherence, all intraresidual NOEs between vicinal protons were allowed to cover a distance range of 1.8–3.7 Å. Torsional angle constraints were calculated from the HNHA experiment and the TALOS (Torsion Angle Likelihood Obtained from Shift and Sequence Similarity) software (39Cornilescu G. Deluglio F. Bax A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1999; 13: 289-302Crossref PubMed Scopus (2740) Google Scholar). A family of structures were calculated by a simulated annealing (SA) approach followed by a refinement procedure using the X-PLOR version 3.1 program package (36Brunger A.T. X-PLOR Software Manual, Version 3.1. Yale University, New Haven, CT1992Google Scholar). For calculation, slightly modified slow-cooling standard simulated annealing protocols were used. Refinement was carried out against the standard covalent geometry restraints. Constraints resulting from NOE intensities, coupling constants, and hydrogen bonds were introduced to the simulated annealing approach in a step by step procedure. Sequential, medium range NOEs as well as long-range NOEs defining the β-sheet regions and coupling constants were used for structure calculation. All the remaining NOEs and hydrogen bonds were subsequently introduced in consecutive steps. The quality of the constraints were checked by analyzing the violations of the calculated conformers. The NOE cross-peaks corresponding to constraints that were consistently violated in a significant number of structures were checked for possible overlap, and the corresponding restraints were consequently modified. The quality of the structures was evaluated using the PROCHECK software (40Laskowski R.A. Moss D.S. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1993; 231: 1049-1067Crossref PubMed Scopus (1087) Google Scholar). The structure of the nFGF-1/SOS complex was generated by Adopted Newton-Raphson restraint minimization with the inclusion of the available intermolecular NOE constraints. The restraint energy minimization process was repeated for few cycles so as to obtain the lowest energy structure(s) and avoid unnecessary bad contacts in the molecule. During this process, the atomic restraints that had been imposed on the nFGF-1 molecule were relaxed. Protein solution was prepared in 100 mm phosphate buffer and 200 mm ammonium sulfate (Millipore) and dried by lyophilization. H/D exchange is initiated by dissolving dry protein in 10 mm phosphate-buffered D2O (pD 6.0, at 25 °C). All NMR data acquisition parameters were preset using a mock sample, and the sample pH was measured after the experiment to minimize the dead-time. The first 1H-15N HSQC spectrum was acquired after 8 min of initiation of exchange. Spectra were recorded with 8 transients of 2048 data points and 64 t1increments. 50 spectra were collected in 48 h with various time points, and another 8 spectra were collected in 1265 h. The peak heights in the two-dimensional spectra were measured using the peak picking subroutine and referenced internally to a nonexchangeable aliphatic proton resonance in the one-dimensional 1H spectra. To determine rate constants for exchange, NH resonance intensities (I) as a function time (t) were fit to a single exponential function, I = Ioexp(-k ex t) + C, where Io is the initial intensity, k ex is the rate constant of exchange, and C is the final amplitude. The protection factor (P) for the various amide protons in the protein were estimated on the basis of the method reported by Bai et al.(41Bai Y. Englander J.J. Mayne L. Milne J.S. Englander S.W. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 259: 344-356Crossref Scopus (100) Google Scholar), using the equation p =k rc/k ex, wherek rc and k ex represent the exchange rates of the protein in the random coil and the native conformation, respectively. As reported by Bai et al. (41Bai Y. Englander J.J. Mayne L. Milne J.S. Englander S.W. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 259: 344-356Crossref Scopus (100) Google Scholar), the hydrogen exchange rates of amide protons in the nonstructured peptides (termed k rc) are estimated by referencing an alanine-based (poly-dl-alanine, PDLA) at low ionic strength at 20 °C. The free energy of exchange of the individual amide protons were calculated from the equation, ΔG ex = -RTln(k ex/k rc), were R is the gas constant and T is the absolute temperature at which the exchange was monitored. Mansukhani A. Deil'Erat P. Beilosta P. Basilico C. RifKin D.B. Moscatelli D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3976-3984Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 47Zhu X. Hsu B.T. Rees D.C. Wang H.M. Leena P.S.T. Chi Y.H. Chen H.C. Wu C.H. Wu R.T. Chang G.G. Chiu I.M. Yu C. Protein Sci. 2002; 11: 1050-1061Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). nFGF-1 in its free form in 10 mmphosphate buffer containing 100 mm each of sodium chloride and ammonium sulfate is found to move as single boundary with a Svedberg constant (S20,w) value of 1.16 S (Supplementary Fig. S1). Time derivative analysis of the data revealed the presence of single species with molecular mass corresponding to 15.7 kDa. Interestingly, nFGF-1 remains as a monomer (S20,W = 1.24 S) even after binding to SOS (M r ∼1293). The molecular mass of nFGF-1 in the SOS-bound state is estimated to be 17.5 kDa. These results are in marked contrast to the crystal structure data on hFGF-1, wherein the protein in the presence of SOS was shown to exist as a dimer. Although, we are currently unable to provide a concrete explanation for the observed discrepancy, we strongly believe that the observation of dimers in the crystal structure (of hFGF-1) is related to the crystallization packing. In this context, it should be pertinent to mention that the solution structure of hFGF-1 in complex with myo-inositol hexasulfate (a heparin functional analog) in solution exists in a monomeric state (48Pineda-Lucena A. Jimenez M.A. Lozano R.M. Nieto J.S. Santoro J. Rico M. Gimenez-Gallego G. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 264: 162-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). 1H,15N, and 13C resonances in nFGF-1 were sequence specifically assigned using the classical method developed by Wuthrich as well as by chain tracing methods based on double and triple resonance NMR experiments (Supplementary Fig. S2 and Refs. 31Bax A. Grzesiek S. Acc. Chem. Res. 1993; 26: 130-138Crossref Scopus (796) Google Scholar, 32Clore G.M. Gronenborn A.M. Protein Sci. 1991; 3: 379-391Google Scholar, and49Wuthrich K. Wider G. Wagner G. Braun W. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 155: 311-319Crossref Scopus (543) Google Scholar). Sequential resonance assignments of nFGF-1 were achieved based on the combined information obtained from the HNCA, HNCOCA, CBCA(CO)NH, and CBCANH spectra. The residues at the N terminus (residues, 23–25) are largely unstructured, as evidenced by the absence of long range NOEs, and the chemical shifts which are close to the random coil state(s). γ, δ, ε resonances of aliphatic chains were traced using CC(CO)NH-TOCSY and HCCH-TOCSY experiments. The aromatic side-chain proton resonances were obtained based on the two-dimensional COSY and TOCSY spectra in conjunction with 15N-edited NOESY data. The aromatic resonance assignments were verified based on the13C-edited NOESY spectra. The chemical shift assignments in nFGF-1 are discussed in detail elsewhere (50Arunkumar A.I. Srisailam S. Kumar T.K.S. Kathir K.M. Peng C.L. Chen C.P. Chiu I.M. Yu C. J. Biomol. NMR. 2000; 17: 279-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar) and have been deposited with the BioMagResBank (accession number, BMRB- 4712). Fig. 2 shows the best-fit superposition of the ensemble of 13 lowest energy nFGF-1 conformers selected from a pool of 50 structures. The structures were computed based on 1359 experimental NMR restraints, consisting of NOE-derived approximate interproton distance constraints, 22 hydrogen-bond derived restraints, and 110 dihedral angle constraints derived from scalar coupling constants. The NMR structure represented by the 13 best conformers represents a good fit of the experimental data, with very small residual constraint violations (<0.3 Å for distance constraints and >3° for dihedral angle constraints). A summary of the structural statistics for the final 13 stimulated annealing structures of nFGF-1 is provided in Table 1. The atomic RMS distribution of the 13 structures about the mean coordinate positions is 0.97 Å for the backbone atoms in the whole protein. The high quality of the nFGF-1 NMR structure is also evident from the results of PROCHECK analysis and by a calculated large negative value for the Lennard Jones/van der Waals energy (−802.39 kcal·mol−1). The regular secondary structural elements in nFGF-1 iden

Glycerol-3-phosphate 1-acyltransferase is a soluble chloroplast enzyme involved in glycerol-lipid biosynthesis associated with chilling resistance in plants (1Murata N. Ishizaki-Nishizawa O. Higashi S. Hayashi H. Tasaka Y. Nishida I. Nature. 1992; 356: 710-713Crossref Scopus (369) Google Scholar). Resistance is associated with higher selectivity for unsaturated acyl substrates over saturated ones. In vitro substrate selectivity assays performed under physiologically relevant conditions have been established that discriminate between selective and non-selective forms of the enzyme. A mutation, L261F, in the squash protein converts it from a non-selective enzyme into a selective one. The mutation lies within 10 Å of the predicted acyl binding site and results in a higherK m for 16:0 acyl carrier protein (ACP). Site-directed mutagenesis was used to determine the importance of four residues, Arg235, Arg237, Lys193, and His194, implicated to be involved in binding of the phosphate group of glycerol 3-phosphate to the enzyme. All the proteins were highly homologous in structure to the wild type enzyme. Mutations in Arg235, Arg237, and Lys193 resulted in inactive enzyme, while His194 had reduced catalytic activity. The mutant proteins retained the ability to bind stoichiometric quantities of acyl-ACPs supporting the potential role of these residues in glycerol 3-phosphate binding. Glycerol-3-phosphate 1-acyltransferase is a soluble chloroplast enzyme involved in glycerol-lipid biosynthesis associated with chilling resistance in plants (1Murata N. Ishizaki-Nishizawa O. Higashi S. Hayashi H. Tasaka Y. Nishida I. Nature. 1992; 356: 710-713Crossref Scopus (369) Google Scholar). Resistance is associated with higher selectivity for unsaturated acyl substrates over saturated ones. In vitro substrate selectivity assays performed under physiologically relevant conditions have been established that discriminate between selective and non-selective forms of the enzyme. A mutation, L261F, in the squash protein converts it from a non-selective enzyme into a selective one. The mutation lies within 10 Å of the predicted acyl binding site and results in a higherK m for 16:0 acyl carrier protein (ACP). Site-directed mutagenesis was used to determine the importance of four residues, Arg235, Arg237, Lys193, and His194, implicated to be involved in binding of the phosphate group of glycerol 3-phosphate to the enzyme. All the proteins were highly homologous in structure to the wild type enzyme. Mutations in Arg235, Arg237, and Lys193 resulted in inactive enzyme, while His194 had reduced catalytic activity. The mutant proteins retained the ability to bind stoichiometric quantities of acyl-ACPs supporting the potential role of these residues in glycerol 3-phosphate binding. Glycerol-3-phosphate 1-acyltransferase (G3PAT, 1The abbreviations used are: G3PAT, glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase; ACP, acyl carrier protein; BSA, bovine serum albumin; G-3-P, glycerol 3-phosphate; LPA, lysophosphatidic acid; 18:1, oleic acid; 16:0, palmitic acid (plsb), EC 2.3.1.15) catalyzes the first acylation step in glycerol lipid biosynthesis acylating the sn1 position of glycerol 3-phosphate (G-3-P). Both soluble and membrane-bound forms of the enzyme exist (2Slabas A.R. Hanley Z. Schierer T. Rice D. Turnbull A. Rafferty J. Simon J.W. Brown A. J. Plant Physiol. 2001; 158: 505-513Crossref Scopus (8) Google Scholar). In Escherichia coli the enzyme is membrane-bound and uses both acyl-ACP and acyl-CoA as substrates (3Green P.R. Merrill A.H.R. Bell R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 11151-11159Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Plants contain soluble and membrane-bound forms of the enzyme, the former being located in the chloroplast and the latter being extraplastidial (2Slabas A.R. Hanley Z. Schierer T. Rice D. Turnbull A. Rafferty J. Simon J.W. Brown A. J. Plant Physiol. 2001; 158: 505-513Crossref Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 4Frentzen M. Heinz E. McKeon T.A. Stumpf P.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1983; 129: 629-636Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). Soluble G3PAT has strong substrate selectivity for acyl-ACP over acyl-CoAs, consistent with the location of both the enzyme and ACP within the chloroplast (4Frentzen M. Heinz E. McKeon T.A. Stumpf P.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1983; 129: 629-636Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). Both selective (4Frentzen M. Heinz E. McKeon T.A. Stumpf P.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1983; 129: 629-636Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar, 5Weber S. Wolter F. Buck F. Frentzen M. Heinz E. Plant Mol. Biol. 1991; 17: 1067-1076Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 6Nishida I. Tasaka Y. Shiraishi H. Murata N. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 21: 267-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar) and non-selective forms of the enzyme have been isolated from plants (Ref.7Frentzen M. Nishida I. Murata N. Plant Cell Physiol. 1987; 28: 1195-1201Google Scholar and oil palm in this report). Non-selective enzymes utilize 16:0 and 18:1 substrates at the same rate, while selective enzymes preferentially incorporate 18:1. Chilling sensitive plants preferentially incorporate C16 saturated fatty acids at position 1, while chilling-resistant plants have a much higher content of unsaturated fatty acids at that position (8Murata N. Plant Cell Physiol. 1983; 24: 81-86Crossref Scopus (198) Google Scholar). As a consequence the glycerolipids of chilling-resistant plants are more fluid at lower temperatures and hence less sensitive to chilling damage. Transgenic studies with tobacco using constructs containing selective (Arabidopsis) and non-selective (squash AT2) G3PATs targeted to the chloroplast supported this view (1Murata N. Ishizaki-Nishizawa O. Higashi S. Hayashi H. Tasaka Y. Nishida I. Nature. 1992; 356: 710-713Crossref Scopus (369) Google Scholar). G3PAT is nuclear-encoded, and import into the chloroplast requires a transit peptide, which is removed to give the mature protein. The exact nature of the processing site has not been determined experimentally (9Ishizaki O. Nishida I. Agata K. Eguchi G. Murata N. FEBS Lett. 1988; 238: 424-430Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 10Murata N. Tasaka Y. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1348: 10-16Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). Transformation experiments performed in tobacco utilizing the truncated form of the squash enzyme linked to the Rubisco (ribulose-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase) transit peptide have demonstrated that this form of the enzyme is both biologically active and non-selective in vivo (1Murata N. Ishizaki-Nishizawa O. Higashi S. Hayashi H. Tasaka Y. Nishida I. Nature. 1992; 356: 710-713Crossref Scopus (369) Google Scholar). The primary structure of mature soluble plant G3PAT is highly conserved. Comparison of the amino acid sequences of the putative mature protein from spinach, pea, and Arabidopsis, all of which show substrate preference for 18:1 over 16:0, reveals that in the mature sequence 199 residues are absolutely conserved between all three of these species. Of these 19 are different in squash; thus it is difficult to identify discrete amino acid residues that could play a major role in determining substrate selectivity. It is also highly likely, as with the oleate desaturase/hydroxylase (11Broun P. Shanklin J. Whittle E. Somerville C. Science. 1998; 282: 1315-1317Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar), that several residues contribute to substrate selectivity, and no one residue has a dominating effect. Determining the nature of the acyl-ACP and G-3-P binding sites will be of importance as a step in elucidating the mechanism of substrate selectivity of this enzyme. The reaction proceeds via a compulsory ordered ternary complex with acyl-ACP binding before G-3-P (12Hayman M.W. Fawcett T Slabas A.R. FEBS Lett. 2002; 514: 281-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). The molecular structure of squash G3PAT has been determined at 1.9-Å resolution (13Turnbull A.P. Rafferty J.B. Sedelnikova S.E. Slabas A.R. Schierer T.P. Kroon J.T.M. Simon J.W. Fawcett T. Nishida I. Murata N. Rice D. Structure (Lond.). 2001; 9: 347-353Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Crystals containing bound substrates could not be obtained; however modeling of the G-3-P and acyl-ACP binding site was performed on the basis of proximity to the conserved H(X)4D motif, which has been shown to be important in catalysis among glycerolipid acyltransferases (14Heath R.J. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1998; 180: 1425-1430Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). From the crystal structure it has been predicted that the phosphate group of G-3-P lies in a positively charged pocket formed by the side chains of two arginine residues Arg235 and Arg237, a lysine, Lys193, and a histidine residue, His194. The presumptive acyl-ACP site was modeled by maximization of the substrate contacts with fully conserved residues across the G3PAT family and the positioning of the reactive sulfur of the fatty acid moiety close to the sn1 position of the modeled G-3-P site. This placed the palmitoyl/pantothene substrate within a deep hydrophobic cleft lined with 14 residues which make van der Waals contacts with the substrate. We are now in a position to test the predicted models for residues implicated to be important in G-3-P and acyl-ACP binding via site-directed mutagenesis. Appropriate assays need to be in place to determine whether any change in in vitro substrate selectivity occurred, since assaying with a single substrate may mistake change in selectivity with total loss of activity. Assays with G3PAT, in the literature, have been performed under a variety of different conditions; hence we have decided to develop assays pertinent to known physiological conditions. The pH of the stroma in the light is pH 8.0 and pH 7.4 in the dark (15Leegood R.C. Lea P.J. Leegood R.C. Plant Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. John Wiley and Sons, Chichester, UK1993: 30-45Google Scholar). Estimates of the concentration of G-3-P vary between 65–90 μm in spinach (16Sauer A. Heise K.P. Z. Naturforsch. C. 1984; 39: 593-599Crossref Scopus (11) Google Scholar) and 450–620 μm in Amaranthus (17Cronan Jr., J.E. Roughan P.G. Plant Physiol. 1987; 83: 676-679Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Chloroplast acyl-ACP concentration values vary in the literature between 0.6–1.9 μm and 0.4–2.0 μm for C16:0 and C18:1 acyl-ACP, respectively (18Roughan G. Nishida I. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1990; 276: 38-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 19Sol J. Roughan G. FEBS Lett. 1982; 146: 189-192Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar). In this paper we report on 1) in vitro assays that can distinguish between selective and non-selective G3PATs performed under physiological relevant conditions, 2) the effect of mutation of Lys193, Arg235, Arg237, and His194, proposed to be involved with binding of the phosphate group of G-3-P, on biological activity and acyl-ACP binding, 3) the conversion of non-selective squash enzyme into a selective one by site-directed mutagenesis resulting in an alteration of theK m for 16:0 ACP. X-ray crystallography has been performed with the protein variants and has shown that the structures are highly homologous to the wild type protein. A 111 day post anthesis oil palm (Elaeis guineesis) mesocarp cDNA library was constructed in the λZAPII cloning vector (Stratagene) using the TimeSaver cDNA synthesis kit (Pharmacia) to prepare EcoRI flanked double-stranded cDNA. A 2043-bp cDNA sequence encoding oil palm G3PAT was isolated from this library by heterologous screening of 2 × 105 plaque-forming unit with a32P-labeled 1445-bp EcoRI cDNA fragment ofArabidopsis G3PAT. Overexpression of squash (NA4, Q24a, Q17b, and JKSQ+), Arabidopsis (AR1) and oil palm constructs for G3PAT (Fig. 1) was carried out using the pETTM plasmid overexpression system. Typical levels of overexpression of plant G3PAT were 10–15% of the totalE. coli proteins. For substrate selectivity and kinetic analyses recombinant G3PAT was selectively released from the E. coli cells by repeated cycles of freezing and thawing in dry ice/ethanol and ice/water (20Johnson B.H. Hecht M.H. Bio/Technology. 1994; 12: 1357-1360Crossref PubMed Scopus (211) Google Scholar) and the concentration adjusted to give standard amounts in each assay. Site-directed mutations of squash and oil palm G3PAT were generated using the QuikChangeTMsite-directed mutagenesis kit from Stratagene (21Simon, J. W., Molecular and Structural Studies on Proteins Involved in Lipid Biosynthesis in Plants and Bacteria.Ph.D. thesis, 2002, University of Durham, Durham, UK.Google Scholar). [14C]Palmitic and [3H]oleic acyl-ACPs were synthesized using 25 μm[14C]palmitic or [3H]oleic acid at a specific activity of 55 Ci/mol and 33 μm recombinantE. coli holo-ACP in a reaction catalyzed by 5 μm E. coli acyl-ACP synthetase. The reaction was carried out in a total volume of 5.0 ml containing 100 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 400 mm LiCl, 10 mm MgCl2, 2 mm dithiothreitol, 5 mm ATP, 1% Triton X-100 and proceeded at 30 °C for 10 h. Following synthesis the radioactive acyl-ACP reaction product was purified away from the other reaction components using anion exchange (Q Sepharose) and hydrophobic interaction (octyl-Sepharose) chromatography. Dual substrate specificity assays using radioactive acyl-ACP substrates were carried out using modified reaction conditions of Frentzen et al.(7Frentzen M. Nishida I. Murata N. Plant Cell Physiol. 1987; 28: 1195-1201Google Scholar). Assays were carried out in 250 mm HEPES buffer, pH 8.0, 300 μm G-3-P, 5.0 mg/ml BSA with 14C 16:0 ACP and 3H 18:1 ACP at 1.1 μm each, in a total volume of 320 μl. Assays were started with the addition of 200 ng of G3PAT purified protein. 80-μl aliquots were removed at 0 (before addition of enzyme), 1, 2, and 3 min and mixed with 710 μl of chloroform/methanol (1:1). 280 μl of 0.2 mH2PO4 in 1 m KCl was added to the samples, which were vigorously mixed and the phases separated by centrifugation. 250 μl of the lower (LPA containing) layer were removed, dried in a vacuum centrifuge, re-suspended in 280 μl of methanol, and mixed with 4 ml of Ecoscint A. Samples were counted in a Packard liquid scintillation counter on a 14C/3H dual counting protocol to determine the rate of incorporation of 14C 16:0 ACP and 3H 18:1 ACP into LPA. The initial velocities were linear. Binding assays with mutant G3PAT enzymes and acyl-ACP substrates were carried out using a UltrafreeTM microconcentrator (Millipore). 100 pmol of radiolabeled acyl-ACP (18:1 ACP) was incubated with 50 pmol of G3PAT enzyme in the absence of the other substrate for 5 min in 200 μl of 250 mm HEPES buffer, pH 8.0. Following incubation the samples were transferred to the concentrator and centrifuged through aM r 30,000 cut-off membrane. The radiolabeled substrate bound to G3PAT was retained by the membrane in the upper compartment of the concentrator. Sample volume in both compartments was readjusted to 200 μl and the sample removed and added to 4 ml of Ecoscint A scintillation fluid prior to counting in a Packard liquid scintillation counter. This membrane did not retain acyl-ACPs in the absence of G3PAT. X-ray crystallography and modeling of substrates within the structure of squash G3PAT was carried out as described previously (13Turnbull A.P. Rafferty J.B. Sedelnikova S.E. Slabas A.R. Schierer T.P. Kroon J.T.M. Simon J.W. Fawcett T. Nishida I. Murata N. Rice D. Structure (Lond.). 2001; 9: 347-353Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). DNA sequencing of all G3PAT constructs was carried out on an Applied Biosystems 377 automated sequencer using forward and reverse primers flanking the position of the G3PAT insert. Primers specific to regions close to mutation sites were also used to confirm the presence of the correct mutation. General molecular biology reagents and restriction enzymes were obtained from Roche Molecular Biochemicals or Stratagene. pET expression vectors came from Novagen, and competentE. coli cells were from Stratagene. Oligonucleotide primers for cloning and mutagenesis reactions were from MWG Biotech. [14C]Palmitic and [3H]oleic acids were supplied by Amersham Biosciences. All other reagents were purchased from Sigma or Merck. Assays were performed under competitive conditions with two substrates in the reaction mixture, 18:1 and 16:0 acyl-ACP at a concentration of 1.1 μm each, which is close to their physiological concentration. Since BSA has routinely been used in assays for G3PAT, we chose to include it in these studies. Two different BSA concentrations were used, 0.5 and 5 mg/ml, referred to, respectively, as low and high. Two different pH values were used, pH 7.4 and pH 8.0, reflecting the pH of the chloroplast in the dark and the light respectively. The G-3-P concentration was 300 μm, which is in the physiological range of this substrate. With the squash enzyme (Fig. 2) both reaction velocities are lower at pH 7.4 than at pH 8.0. At high BSA there is little preference for either 16:0 or 18:1, while at low BSA there is a preference for 18:1 over 16:0, which is more marked at the lower pH. At low BSA, in comparison with high BSA, the reaction velocity is lowered for 16:0 and increased for 18:1 resulting in an alteration of the substrate selectivity of the enzyme. Assays conducted with the full-length sequence of the squash enzyme (JSKQ+) in the presence of high BSA and pH 8.0 gave a substrate selectivity of 0.93, which is close to that observed for the truncated enzyme. With theArabidopsis enzyme (Fig. 2) similar effects are seen; however under all assay conditions the Arabidopsis enzyme shows a strong preference for 18:1. As the physiological concentrations of G-3-P and acyl-ACP could be as high as 2 μm for acyl-ACPs and 620 μm for G-3-P, we conducted further selectivity assays increasing the acyl-ACP and G-3-P concentration at high BSA and pH 8.0. The G-3-P concentration was increased up to 620 μm and the acyl-ACP up to a concentration of 2.2 μm each. Assays were conducted with both the squash and Arabidopsis enzymes (TableI). Doubling the acyl-ACP or G-3-P concentration had little effect on the substrate selectivity. We therefore decided to use a 1.1 μm concentration of each acyl-ACP, 300 μm G-3-P, high BSA and pH 8.0 in all future experimentation.Table ISubstrate selectivity assays of squash and Arabidopsis G3PAT using varying levels of acyl-ACP and G3P substratesConcentration of each acyl-ACPaEquimolar mixtures of 18:1 and 16:0 ACP were used in the reaction mixture, each at the concentration given.[G3P]Rates for 18:1/16:0 LPA productionSelectivity (18:1/16:0)bSelectivity is given as the rate of production of 18:1 LPA divided by the rate of production of 16:0 LPA.μmμmpmol/minSquash G3PAT (Q24a)1.130012.4/13.00.951.162015.6/17.30.92.230018.2/15.21.2Arabidopsis G3PAT (AR1)1.130020.1/6.53.11.162025.9/9.652.72.230030.1/8.63.5a Equimolar mixtures of 18:1 and 16:0 ACP were used in the reaction mixture, each at the concentration given.b Selectivity is given as the rate of production of 18:1 LPA divided by the rate of production of 16:0 LPA. Open table in a new tab To prepare large quantities of squash G3PAT, using fermentation, for more extensive crystallization trials, we decided to replace the ampicillin selection marker with a kanamycin one. This was to overcome problems with loss of the plasmid due to the expense of maintaining the organism under ampicillin selection in the fermenter. In our cloning strategy we amplified the squash G3PAT cDNA from the plasmid pNA4 via a PCR-based protocol using a proof reading Taq polymerase (VENTTM DNA Polymerase) and inserted it into the pET24a plasmid, which contains a kanamycin selection marker. Assays using the dual substrate 16:0/18:1 acyl-ACP selectivity assay were performed on selected transformants. It was noticed that G3PAT from one of the transformants showed a preference for 18:1 (Fig.3 d), while the “wild type” plasmid from which it was derived exhibited no acyl preference (Fig.3 a). Sequencing of the entire coding region for G3PAT in the “mutant” plasmid revealed that two point mutations had occurred during the PCR reactions. These converted Leu261 and Ser331 to Phe and Pro, respectively (Fig. 3 d). To identify which residue was responsible for this change in substrate selectivity, both mutated residues were individually mutated back to the wild type. The L261F enzyme was selective (Fig. 3 b), while the S331P was non-selective (Fig. 3 c), indicating that a point mutation at 261 converts a non-selective enzyme into a selective one. To see if mutation at this residue could result in altered substrate selectivity in other G3PAT enzymes, we looked for the corresponding residue in the oil palm G3PAT, which we had recently cloned, and which shows no substrate selectivity. The corresponding residue in oil palm is Leu352. We mutated this to a Phe and assayed for substrate selectivity. Mutation of this residue in oil palm caused a similar alteration in substrate selectivity (Fig. 3, e and f). Position 261 in the squash G3PAT structure lies at the end of the deep cleft remote from the H(X)4D motif and represents one of 12 residues implicated in binding the fatty acyl substrate (13Turnbull A.P. Rafferty J.B. Sedelnikova S.E. Slabas A.R. Schierer T.P. Kroon J.T.M. Simon J.W. Fawcett T. Nishida I. Murata N. Rice D. Structure (Lond.). 2001; 9: 347-353Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). The fact that the structures of the wild type and L261F variant are otherwise identical suggests that differential substrate specificity could arise in part from the large side chain of the phenylalanine residue. To determine the basis of the alteration in substrate selectivity we performed kinetic analysis on the wild type and mutant enzymes from squash. Assays were performed using acyl-ACP at 10 μmeach and G-3-P at 20 mm at pH 8.0 in the presence of 5 mg/ml BSA, while varying the second substrate concentration. The K m andV max for both G-3-P and acyl-ACP (Fig.4) are almost identical for the wild type and mutant using 18:1 ACP as substrate; however, theK m for 16:0 in the mutant was almost three times as high (Table II). The reaction velocity of both Q24a N-terminally truncated recombinant protein and the Q24a-L261F mutant were determined at 20 mm G-3-P and 10 μm of both 16:0 and 18:1 ACP (total acyl-ACP concentration 20 μm). Open table in a new tab The H(X)4D motif is present in G3PAT and is hypothesized to be involved in metal binding, and the D331E mutant ofplsb in E. coli is still capable of binding G-3-P, albeit with an increased K m of 200 μm in comparison with 100 μm for the wild type. By analogy with chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (22Lewin T.M. Wang P. Coleman R.A. Biocemistry. 1999; 38: 5764-5771Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar) it has been argued that the His residue could act as a general base to abstract a proton from the hydroxy group of the acyl acceptor to facilitate nucleophilic attack on the thioester of the acyl donor. It is notable that in all 18:1-selective G3PATs the sequence is HQSEAD, while in the squash enzyme, which is non-selective, the Ser is a Thr (141). The corresponding residue in oil palm is also a Thr (169). Mutation of Thr141 to an Ser in the squash enzyme does not result in any major alteration in substrate selectivity of the protein (Table III). It is still fully catalytically active and shows the same substrate preference, indicating that this single residue does not play a major role in determining substrate selectivity.Table IIISummary of squash G3PAT Q24a mutants created and analyzedMutant (based on Q24a numbering)Activity as % of wild type (standardizedng of GPAT protein added)aPercentage activity is calculated by assigning the wild type enzyme an activity of 100% and comparing the LPA formed per min (of 18:1 and 16:0 ACP together) against that of the wild type.Selectivity (if determined)Q24a100 (arbitrary)1.0T141S1061.0E142AbThese assays were performed for up to 100 times the normal incubation time to confrim lack of activity.0K193SbThese assays were performed for up to 100 times the normal incubation time to confrim lack of activity.0H194S790.8R235SbThese assays were performed for up to 100 times the normal incubation time to confrim lack of activity.0R237SbThese assays were performed for up to 100 times the normal incubation time to confrim lack of activity.0L261F903.8S331P941.2Oil palm wild type1001.1Oil palm L352F1173.3a Percentage activity is calculated by assigning the wild type enzyme an activity of 100% and comparing the LPA formed per min (of 18:1 and 16:0 ACP together) against that of the wild type.b These assays were performed for up to 100 times the normal incubation time to confrim lack of activity. Open table in a new tab From the crystal structure it has been predicted that the G-3-P binding site lies in domain 2 of the protein and that the phosphate group lies in a positively charged pocket formed by the side chains of two arginine residues Arg235 and Arg237, a lysine, Lys193, and a histidine residue, His194 (Fig. 5). We mutated each of the four positively charged residues and converted them individually to serine residues. The proteins were expressed inE. coli at the same level as the wild type protein and were fully soluble. The soluble protein was assayed for biological activity using the standard assay with acyl-ACPs (Table III). R235S, R237S, and K193S were all inactive, even following incubation times 100 times longer than those normally used. In acyl-ACP binding studies using a spin column, all three inactive enzymes retained their ability to bind stoichiometric quantities of acyl-ACP. The values for nanomoles of acyl ACP substrate bound per mole of enzyme were 0.95 + 0.01, 0.81 + 0.03, 0.91 + 0.02, 0.91 + 0.05, and 0.90 + 0.03 for Q24a, E142A, K193S, R235S, and R237S, respectively. Since the reaction proceeds via an ordered ternary complex with acyl-ACP binding first, the results are consistent with the three residues being involved in G-3-P binding. The H194S mutant had ∼80% of the biological activity of the wild type enzyme, indicating that this residue is not so critical for binding and catalysis. We also mutated Glu142, which lies in the H(X)4D box to Ala. This residue is conserved in all plant G3PAT enzymes. The resultant E142A protein is biologically inactive, indicating that it plays an important role in the enzyme. Replacing the Glu with an Ala changes the local hydrogen bonding environment close to the presumptive G-3-P binding site and presumably perturbs the structure in such a way that the enzyme is catalytically inactive. High resolution x-ray diffraction data were collected for crystals of the K193S, R235S, and R237S mutant enzymes, and the three-dimensional structures were solved using molecular replacement methods employing programs from the CCP4 suite (data not shown). Pairwise superposition using the program LSQKAB (23Collaborative Computational Project Number 4 Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1994; 50: 760-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (19797) Google Scholar) of the structures of the mutant enzymes with that of the wild type G3PAT structure gave root mean square displacements of Cα positions ranging between 0.1 and 0.3 Å, which indicate that the structures of these enzymes are highly homologous. Therefore, the replacement of any of these residues with a serine residue inactivates the enzyme without major perturbation of the three-dimensional structure. Additionally, the structure of the L261F mutant is also highly homologous to the wild type structure with a root mean square displacement of Cα distances of 0.1 Å. Introduction of E. coli (24Wolter F.P. Schmidt R. Heinz E. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 4685-4692Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar) and plant plsb genes (1Murata N. Ishizaki-Nishizawa O. Higashi S. Hayashi H. Tasaka Y. Nishida I. Nature. 1992; 356: 710-713Crossref Scopus (369) Google Scholar), which code for the non-selective enzyme into tobacco, has confirmed the importance of the acyl group composition on chilling resistance in plants. Studies using chimeric protein constructs between the pea and the squash enzymes have indicated that the central portion of the enzyme is probably important in substrate selectivity (25Ferri S.R. Toguri T. Arch. Biochim. Biophys. 1997; 337: 202-208Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). However these studies have been compromised by the use of non-physiological conditions and substrate analogues. In this study we have developed in vitro assays that discriminate between selective and non-selective plant G3PATs. It is interesting to note that BSA, which is known to bind fatty acids, has a significant effect on this assay, prompting us to suggest that chloroplasts may contain an acyl-binding protein equivalent to the acyl-CoA-binding protein present in the cytoplasm (26Brown A.P. Johnson P. Rawsthorne S. Hills M.J. Plant Physiol. Biochem. 1998; 36: 629-635Crossref Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Mutation of a single residue L261F causes major changes in substrate selectivity, and from modeling studies this is likely to be due to masking of the hydrophobic cleft. The exact nature of the interactions between the enzyme and fatty acyl substrate awaits further three-dimensional structural data on a binary complex of the enzyme with substrate. However, the modeling studies combined with the site-directed mutagenesis studies presented here have indicated that changing Leu261 to a phenylalanine residue alters specificity from a non-selective enzyme to one that preferentially incorporates C18:1 ACP. Given that our crystallographic studies reveal no other changes in enzyme structure, the bulky hydrophobic nature of the phenylalanine side chain must alter the shape of the binding pocket so that a lower binding affinity and rate of catalysis are observed with the C16:0 substrate (K m three times higher andK cat 50%), while the affinity and catalytic rate with the C18:1 substrate remain unchanged compared with the wild type protein. Since knowledge of the active site of the enzyme is important to understand how it functions, we have performed site-directed mutagenesis on amino acid residues proposed from modeling studies to be involved in G-3-P and acyl-ACP binding. Our results are consistent with Lys193, Arg235, and Arg237 as residues important in binding the negatively charged phosphate group of G-3-P. Clear evidence cannot be obtained on the site of acyl-ACP binding, and this will require further studies either using a catalytically inactive enzyme to obtain a suitable enzyme complex or appropriate binding studies using photo-affinity probes. Such studies will be the basis of future work.

Amphetamine (AMPH) is a drug of abuse that causes the degeneration of striatal dopamine terminals in mammals. Superoxide radicals seem to participate in AMPH-induced damage because its toxicity is attenuated in Cu/Zn superoxide dismutase transgenic (SOD-tg) mice. To provide a detailed analysis of molecular changes associated with AMPH toxicity, we used cDNA arrays consisting of 1176 genes to detect differential changes in gene expression in the striata of wild-type and SOD-tg mice treated with neurotoxic doses of the drug. We found 42 genes that showed >1.8-fold changes in at least two consecutive time points during the course of the study and were differentially affected by AMPH in the two genotypes. Specifically, more transcription factors and genes involved in responses to injury/inflammation were affected in wild-type mice after AMPH administration. Some of these stimulant-induced superoxide-dependent alterations in gene expression might affect neuronal functions and promote neuronal damage. Other changes might help to provide some degree of protection against AMPH toxicity. These results support the view that the use of global array analysis of gene expression will help to identify novel molecular mediators of AMPH-induced neurodegeneration.

Leukocytic inflammation can be limited by inhibiting selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling. In spite of intensive efforts to develop small molecule selectin inhibitors with defined structure-activity profiles, inhibition of P-selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling in vivo by such a compound has yet to be described. We recently reported that glycosulfopeptides (GSP), modeled on the high affinity selectin ligand PSGL-1, inhibit leukocyte binding to P-selectin in vitro. Here, we have used intravital microscopy to investigate whether GSP can inhibit P-selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling in vivo. Surgical preparation of the mouse cremaster muscle for intravital microscopy induced P-selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling. Baseline rolling was recorded for 1 min followed by i.v. injection of GSP. 2-GSP-6 and 4-GSP-6 substantially reversed P-selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling, whereas control GSP, which are not fully glycosylated, did not. Inhibition of leukocyte rolling by 2- and 4-GSP-6 lasted 2-4 min. Clearance studies with 125I-labeled 4-GSP-6 demonstrated rapid reduction in its circulating levels concurrent with accumulation in urine. These data represent the first demonstration that a precisely defined structure based on a natural P-selectin ligand can inhibit P-selectin-dependent leukocyte rolling in vivo.
